qas.question: The advancement of agriculture made what possible?
Having a surplus of food allowed farmers and hunter-gatherers to spend less time working on what?
Before agriculture advancements, what were farmers having to do?
What advancement aided in spreading knowledge across generations?
Who was able to support the people who were adding to the written knowledge of nature?

context: <a3_0>The development of writing<a3_0/> enabled knowledge to be stored and communicated across generations with much greater fidelity. Combined with the development of agriculture, which allowed for <a0_0>a surplus of food<a0_0/>, it became possible for early civilizations to develop, because more time and effort could be devoted to tasks (other than <a1_0>food production<a1_0/>) than hunter-gatherers or early subsistence farmers had available. This surplus allowed a <a4_0>community<a4_0/> to support individuals who did things other than <a2_0>work towards bare survival<a2_0/>. These other tasks included systematic studies of nature, study of written information gathered and recorded by others, and often of adding to that body of information.
